div.head: XCVIII.

OF MAR SEVERUS FROM THE 5th LETTER OF THE 4th BOOK OF THOSE AFTER EXILE, WHICH WAS ADDRESSED TO CAESARIA THE HYPATISSA, WHICH BEGINS, "When I read the letter of your magnificence's love of God, not once nor twice".
div.p:
But to the question which your excellency's magnificence has asked me by letter I return an easy answer, that for my part I have never accepted or expressed agreement with those who speak of an apokatastasis, and an end to the judgment involved in the torments that are threatened us in the future world, and the man who says that he has a letter of mine which proclaims this opinion manifestly lies. Therefore I praised your God-loving magnificence for asking for such a letter to be shown to you; a letter which the man who concocted it necessarily set himself falsely to show to be my composition. Those who hold such an opinion, wishing to accomplish their desires, as if forsooth on the basis of plausible suppositions, make use of arguments that are gratifying to the hearers, saying that it is unbecomingto or unworthy
of God, and far removed from his mercifulness, that the man who has sinned for 50 or 100 years in this world should endure torments for unending ages, forgetting this, that God's laws and those which, prevail among men think fit to requite sins according to the intention of the sinner, and one may hear even wise men outside saying of certain persons who have done foul deeds and acts that are not permitted, "This man deserves to die not once but many times"This seems to be a citation, but I do not know the source.. But, when a man hears as we do that God who became incarnate and was humanized without variation for our salvation, and who for this reason came down from heaven and conversed with us plainly threatens (EKT) 'became
... salvation, and that for
... reason he came
... heaven, plainly threatening'. fire that is not quenched and an undying wormMark ix, 44., and (EKT) ins. 'after all these things'. This version has many additions, which from a comparison with the originals of the citations contained in the extract I infer to be interpolations. makes light of it, how does he not deserve, if it is possible to say so, to be condemned
twice over to (EKT) ins. 'eternal fire and'. endless torment? If a man live 100 years or more in this present world and spend such a period in vanity, it is certain that this man, if he were allowed to live this same temporal life (EKT) om. without end (EKT) ins. 'remaining without death'., would not cease from his eternal (EKT) om. greed and wantonness (EKT) ins. 'and lasciviousness and a foul life in lusts'.. How therefore will this man in accordance with his disposition not justly be tormented without end? Even the very men who introduce an apokatastasis (ET) ins. 'or end of judgment'. say of sinners that they will be tormented for many (ET) ins. 'years'. and long periods so to speak (ET) 'of such a kind and protracted future ages'., and then afterwards will be purified and admitted to clemency and attain to the promised blessedness. But theyIn another version (ET) 'those who say these things'. forget that their human reasonings
themselves show God to be unrighteous in his judgmentsA.v. (ET) 'and unjust'.. If a man lives (ET) ins. 'up and down'. in sin 50 or 80 years, but (ET) ins. 'is requited with a severe sentence and'. endures torments many long generations, it is again apparent on their principle that this is not worthy of God's mercifulness (E) ins. 'nor yet becoming to the kindness existing in him'., to extend the period of torment beyond the time of the life in sins, If God agreed with the reasonings of those who think thusA.v. (E) ins. 'and agreed and assented to their opinions'., the man who sins for 50 years should endure torment for 50 years, and it (E) 'only, and the judgment.' should not be thus long extended over many generations, as they sayIn another version (E) ins. 'and his torment endure for ages'. What follows to 'distinction' (p. 374 l. 4) isomitted in vers. F.. For our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ also, in the holy words of his preaching, when
separating the righteous from the sinners, said, "These shall go to eternal torment, and the righteous to eternal life"Matth. xxv, 46., and with regard to both the classesτάγμα., that of the former and that of the latter, he spoke in exactly the same fashion of an equality without distinction, applying the word ' eternal' to both without distinction. Basil the great among teachers of the truth shows this clearly in the teaching composed by him in the form of question and answer addressed to the brethren of the convents; and it is the 219th question, which is expressed as follows: "The brethren say (F) 'when be was asked by the brethren'. 'IfIn another version (EKL) ins. 'it is said of the two slaves described in the gospel that'; Bas. om. one shall be beaten with many stripes and another with few, how
say some that there is no end to the sentence of those who are tormented?'

Points which are matters of dispute and seen to be obscurely expressed m various places of the Holy Scriptures are elucidated by clear statements in other places. Since therefore our Lord says at one time, 'These shall go into eternal torment (F) and EL ins. 'and the righteous into eternal life; Bas. om.', and at another dismisses some to 'the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels', and at another mentions 'the gehenna of fire', uttering further the words,A.v.(EKL) om. 'Where their worm dieth not, and their fire is not quenched', and again said before through the prophet about certain
men, (EKL); "Ye shall go out and see the corpses of them who have committed iniquity against me, for'. 'Their worm shall not die, and their fire shall not be quenched'; while these and similar expressions, are often (F) 'here and there'; Bas. πολλαχοῦ. used in the divine Scriptures, this also was brought about by the machination of the devil, in order that men, forgetting these and similar decrees of our Lord, might presume to sin without restraint, persuading themselves that there is an end to judgment. For, if it is possible for there to beA.v. EKL.) 'it is certain that the devil by his craft contrived to deceive the minds of many, in order that while they forget our Lord's sentences, he may sow this in their thoughts that there
.... judgment, and make them yet more presume
... restraint in the evil deeds of hateful things. For, if there is'; Bas. ἕν κ. τοῦτο τῆς μεθοδείασ τοῦ διαβ., τὸ τοὺς πολλοὐς τῶν ἀνθρώπων ὥσπερ ἐπιλαθομένους τῶν τοσούτων κ. τοιούτων τοῦ Κ. ῥημάτων κ. ἀποφάσενω τέλος κολάσεως εἰς τὸ μαλλόν κατατολμὰν τῆς ἁμαρτίας ἑαυτοῖς ὑπογράφειν. Εἰ γ. τῆς αἰςνίου κολάσεως ἔσται ποτέ. an end to eternal judgment, there will assuredly also be an end to eternal life. But, if we do not consent to think this with regard to (EKL) 'that there is an end to eternal'. life, what plausibility is there in our assigning (EKL) 'room is there for the theory that there is'. an end to eternal judgment? For the addition of the word 'eternal' is made equally in both cases. 'These shall go into eternal
judgment, and the righteous into eternal life'. These things therefore being thus admitted, we must know that the words 'He shall be beaten with many stripes' and 'shall be beaten with few' are not an end, but signify a difference of torment. For, if God is an upright judge, not only to the good but also to the evilA.v. (EK) om., and requites each according to his deeds, it is possible for one to be in the fire that is not quenchedA.V. (EK) ins. 'and another to be in fire'., burning either less or more than the other, and another in the worm that dies not, both one that hurts little and one that hurts muchIn another version (EK) 'and another in bitter habitations, and one in milder torments, and one in torments more severe than they'., each as he deserves, and another in gehenna that has a variety of torments, and another in outer darkness, and that there
is a place where a man is found amidst weeping only, and there is a place where he is amidst gnashing of teeth also from the severity of the painsIn another version(E) 'one may recognise moreover in gehenna a variety of torments of those who are being requited'.. But the outer darkness signifies that there is in truth an inner darkness also. A. v, (E) ins. 'And there is a place of requital where a man is in weeping only, and there is one again where he is in gnashing of teeth, from the severe torments of the bitter sentence'. And the words used in the ProverbsA.v. (F) ins. 'of Solomon'. 'at the bottom of Sheol (E) 'bringeth down to the depths of Sheol and to the bottom of the pit'.' signify that there are persons in Sheol and not at the bottom of it, because their torment is smaller (E) ins. 'and there is one who is in the pit and not as it were at the bottom of it. By all which things the difference is signified of the retribution in the judgment of those who are requited as their deeds deserve, either by a severe sentence or by a vengeance with mitigation in it according to their acts'.. And this is depicted now also in bodily afflictions. For there is aman who is in a fever together with other pains, and another
who is in a fever only, and the latter is not like the former, and another has no fever, but is troubled by pain in some limb 1. A.v. (E) 'other pains of every kind'., and one again either less or more than another. But this expression 'much' or 'little' is employed by our Lord in accordance with customary usage, as are also many other similar phrases. For we know that this form of speech is frequently adopted even with regard to those who are suffering from one disease (E) ins. 'or illness'. . For example, in the case of a man who has a fever only, or has pain in the eye only (E) om. we (F) 'they'. say in astonishment 'How much he has suffered!' or 'What anguish he has endured!' Accordingly the expression 'shall be beaten with many'
and 'with few', I say again, stands not in the extent of the time and the shortness (E)' which has received an end'; Bas. ἢ συμπληρώσει, which latter word the author of the E version has taken as a verb. ܩܠܝܠܘܬܐ must app. be rendered 'shortness', though this meaning is not otherwise known. , but in the difference of the torment"P. G., XXXI, 1264.. These things this great ruler and shepherd of rational souls Basil taught and stated with great completeness. (F) om. And Gregory, who became bishop of Nazianzus, himself in the homily of defence thinks that the future torment is endless, teaching thus: "But for us, the salvation of whose blessed and immortal soul is in danger, which will be undyingly tormented or glorified (EK) 'gratified in the eternal kingdom'. by reason of wickedness or of virtue, how great do you think should the contest be (EK) ins. 'concerning this'. ?"Or. ii, 28. And John in the 66th homily (EK) ins. 'delivered by him'. of the commentary on the Gospel of Matthew
states things consonant with these as follows: "For all these reasons accordingly let us first pay the taxes; for it is indeed very (EK) 'Before all things let us have a struggle on behalf of good things; for labour for fair things is'. easy, and the reward is greater, and there is great abundance of (F) om. profit, and worse is the torture if we do not understand, and (EK) 'which will be exacted from us, which is'. a torture that has no end"In Matth. Hom. LXVI, 4 (ed. Par. 2a, VII, 742).. And the same again in the 79th exposition when speaking of the Passion referred to the kingdom, and to the endless torment.A. v. (F) om. And in the 82nd about the man who approaches (E) ins. 'our Saviour's body and blood'. the communion of the holy mysteries in a careless mood and without caution he gives teaching in the following words: "He who approaches after he has sinned is worse than a demoniac; for the: latter because they have a demon (E) 'are involuntarily controlled by demons'. do not receive punishmentIn another version (E) ins. 'and are not judged'., but the
former, because they approach unworthily, are delivered to undying tormentA. v. (E) 'judgment without mercy and torment that does not finish'; (F) 'undying torments; Jo. Chrys. ἀθανάτῳ τιμωρίᾳ."Op. cit., LXXXII, 6 (ed. Par. 2a, VII, 890).. And at the end of the commentary on the epistle to the Ephesians he (E) ' the same blessed John again'. expressed himself thus: "For a man to be burnt (EK) ins. 'in gehenna'. and not consumed, and to be perpetually gnawed by aIn another version (EK) 'an undying'. worm is indestructible (EK) ins. 'and unperishing'. destruction, as happened to (EK) 'we hear of'. the blessed Job, who (EK) 'whose body'. was in process of destruction and did not perish for a considerable time, but was constantly suffering and wasting awayA. v. (F) om., while he scraped off putrid matter from his body (EK) 'with a potsherd' (Job, n, 3). Neither is in Jo. Chrys. for a long time. Something similar will happen to the soul at that time, when the (EK) ins. 'undying' worms surround and gnaw it, not for two yearsA. v, (EK) ins. 'only'. nor for ten nor for a hundred nor
for myriadsJo. Chr. μυρίοις., but for years without end; for 'their worm', he says, 'shall not die'"In Ep. ad Eph. Hom. xxiv, 28, 29 (ed. Field).. The wise Cyril (EK) 'blessed C. wise in divine things'. also in the 1st book of the commentary on the Gospel of John said: "We ought not to be ungrateful to God but on the contrary (EK) 'the contrary, i.e.' to thank him because by means of the Resurrection from the dead he has appointed for us torment that does not pass awayIn another version (EK) ins. 'unless we repent completely'."In Jo. Ev., ed. Pusey, I, 119; but our text differs widely..
